messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A New Algorithm for Euclidean Shortest Paths in the PlaneA preliminary version will appear in Proceedings of the 53rd Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (STOC 2021). This research was supported in part by NSF under Grant CCF-2005323.

Paper Abstract: Abstract Given a set of pairwise disjoint polygonal obstacles in the plane, finding an obstacle-avoiding Euclidean shortest path between two points is a classical problem in computational geometry and has been studied extensively. Previously, Hershberger and Suri [SIAM J. Comput. 1999] gave an algorithm of Oâ€‹(nâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(n\log n) time and Oâ€‹(nâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(n\log n) space, where nğ‘›n is the total number of vertices of all obstacles. Recently, by modifying Hershberger and Suriâ€™s algorithm, Wang [SODA 2021] reduced the space to Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) while the runtime of the algorithm is still Oâ€‹(nâ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(n\log n). In this paper, we present a new algorithm of Oâ€‹(n+hâ€‹logâ¡h)ğ‘‚ğ‘›â„â„O(n+h\log h) time and Oâ€‹(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n) space, provided that a triangulation of the free space is given, where hâ„h is the number of obstacles. The algorithm, which improves the previous work when h=oâ€‹(n)â„ğ‘œğ‘›h=o(n), is optimal in both time and space as Î©â€‹(n+hâ€‹logâ¡h)Î©ğ‘›â„â„\Omega(n+h\log h) is a lower bound on the runtime. Our algorithm builds a shortest path map for a source point sğ‘ s, so that given any query point tğ‘¡t, the shortest path length from sğ‘ s to tğ‘¡t can be computed in Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n) time and a shortest sğ‘ s-tğ‘¡t path can be produced in additional time linear in the number of edges of the path.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "The open problem project",
        "L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} shortest path queries in simple polygons",
        "Triangulating disjoint Jordan chains",
        "Computing shortest paths amid convex pseudodisks",
        "Two-point L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} shortest path queries in the plane",
        "Shortest path queries among weighted obstacles in the rectilinear plane",
        "Computing shortest paths among curved obstacles in the plane",
        "A new algorithm for computing visibility graphs of polygonal obstacles in the plane",
        "Computing the visibility polygon of an island in a polygonal domain",
        "Computing L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} shortest paths among polygonal obstacles in the plane",
        "Two-point Euclidean shortest path queries in the plane",
        "Rectilinear shortest paths through polygonal obstacles in Oâ€‹(nâ€‹log2â¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscript2ğ‘›O(n\\log^{2}n) time",
        "Rectilinear shortest paths through polygonal obstacles in Oâ€‹(nâ€‹log2/3â¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›superscript23ğ‘›O(n\\log^{2/3}n) time",
        "Randomized parallel algorithms for trapezoidal diagrams",
        "Rectilinear shortest paths in the presence of rectangular barriers",
        "Making data structures persistent",
        "Optimal point location in a monotone subdivision",
        "Geometric kğ‘˜k shortest paths",
        "An output-sensitive algorithm for computing visibility graphs",
        "Compact interval trees: A data structure for convex hulls",
        "Optimal shortest path queries in a simple polygon",
        "Linear-time algorithms for visibility and shortest path problems inside triangulated simple polygons",
        "A new data structure for shortest path queries in a simple polygon",
        "Geometric kğ‘˜kth shortest paths",
        "Computing minimum length paths of a given homotopy class",
        "An optimal algorithm for Euclidean shortest paths in the plane",
        "A near-optimal algorithm for shortest paths among curved obstacles in the plane",
        "Fast triangulation of the plane with respect to simple polygons",
        "A near optimal algorithm for finding Euclidean shortest path in polygonal domain",
        "An efficient algorithm for Euclidean shortest paths among polygonal obstacles in the plane",
        "Optimal search in planar subdivisions",
        "Tentative prune-and-search for computing fixed-points with applications to geometric computation",
        "Euclidean shortest paths in the presence of rectilinear barriers",
        "An optimal algorithm for shortest rectilinear paths among obstacles",
        "A new algorithm for shortest paths among obstacles in the plane",
        "L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} shortest paths among polygonal obstacles in the plane",
        "Shortest paths among obstacles in the plane",
        "Separation and approximation of polyhedral objects",
        "Optimal algorithm for geodesic nearest-point Voronoi diagrams in simple polygons",
        "Maintenance of configurations in the plane",
        "Shortest paths in the plane with convex polygonal obstacles",
        "On shortest paths in polyhedral spaces",
        "Shortest paths in the plane with polygonal obstacles",
        "Quickest visibility queries in polygonal domains",
        "A divide-and-conquer algorithm for two-point L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} shortest path queries in polygonal domains",
        "Shortest paths among obstacles in the plane revisited"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A New Algorithm for Euclidean Shortest Paths in the PlaneA preliminary version will appear in Proceedings of the 53rd Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing (STOC 2021). This research was supported in part by NSF under Grant CCF-2005323., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
